Young Masters Age is against Bobby Fischer as he tries to re-establish himself. Chess is more than ever a young man's game. After 20 years of self-imposed exile, Mr Bobby Fischer has returned to chess and is playing his old adversary Boris Spassky. Mr Fischer's victory in the first game was a masterpiece, simple but profound. But, as subsequent games have shown, this balding, bearded chess player is not the man of 1972. He is 49 years old, out of practice and out of shape. The game has also changed a lot over the past two decades. The new era of professionalism was born out of Mr Fischer's own popularisation of the game. The rise of the professional chess circuit has seen the competitive aspect of the game overtake the scientific and artistic. The main goal of the modern master is to win. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as crucial as his intellect and wisdom. The pressure of the game has always been intense, but now the playing sessions themselves are becoming longer, and many games are played without a break. The increased pressure has swung the pendulum in youth's favour. Over the past 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than his predecessor. The game is played on a board, but much of modern chess is played off the board. The presence of the chess clock adds to the tension. The climax of the game is often a furious 'time scramble'. With minds racing and hands twitching, the masters blitz out their moves and press their clocks with a co-ordination that any athlete would admire.

Fame and fortune are two things that many people dream of, and there are a few young Brits who are making their dreams a reality.
Nick Grosso is a playwright who has written three critically acclaimed plays. He is currently adapting his first play, Peaches, into a screenplay. He says that it's low budget but he doesn't know how low. It certainly won't be over PS30 million, but it could be 30 quid.
Simon Pegg is a comedian who has written a television comedy series and has just finished a punishing tour around the country with comedy star Steve Coogan. He says that comedy is not the hardest job in the world. If you've got the courage and you've got good material, it's a wonderful thing to make people laugh.
Ciaran McMenamin is an actor who has gained a lot of recognition for his role in the series The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. He says that it's been a really good showcase for him and that he's now in a position where he can pick and choose what he does.
Neil Taylor is a singer in a pop band that has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. He says that the record company's idea of good sales is very different to his. He's been working hard for his success and he's not afraid to admit that he's been in some atrocious bands.
Stephen Richards is a poet and author who has won more prizes, awards and academic honours than anyone twice his age. He says that his main ambition is not to get into a pattern where he's just churning stuff out without worrying about the quality.

In a novel, there is a character named Isabel who is an art student. She is concerned about her knobbly knees ruining her chances of finding Mr Right. However, there is hope for her. The author writes with terrific verve and creates a story that is both funny and touching.
The novel also includes a story about a local radio station in America. The station is called WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio. Francis is a worker at the station. He is intelligent and weedy. The station broadcasts a variety of programs, including singers, preachers, and soap-opera heroes.
The novel also includes a story about a second husband who gossips with his wive's first husband. The poetess writes rotten poetry and tries to get Richards support for her wrongfully imprisoned brother.
The novel is well-written and entertaining. It is a pleasure to read.

International voluntary work can be a rewarding experience for both volunteers and the communities they serve. However, there are some concerns about the impact of volunteer tourism on developing countries.
One concern is that volunteer tourism can be exploitative. When volunteers pay a fee to participate in a project, the money often ends up benefiting the volunteer organization rather than the local community. This can be especially problematic for gap years, where volunteers may not have the skills or experience needed to make a significant contribution to the community.
Another concern is that volunteer tourism can be isolating. If volunteers are not able to interact with the local community, they may not be able to fully experience the benefits of their volunteer work. This can be especially problematic for volunteers who are working on long-term projects.
Despite these concerns, volunteer tourism can also have a positive impact on developing countries. For example, volunteering can lead to greater international understanding, enhanced ability to solve conflicts, and widespread and democratic participation in global affairs. It can also help to develop people who will, in the course of their careers and lives, act ethically in favour of those less well-off.

The clock radio is a common device used to wake people up. To choose a good clock radio, you need to consider several factors. The 'dual alarm function' does not allow you to snooze or be driven out of bed. Instead, it allows you to set two different wake-up times. The inclusion of a cassette player is a great feature, allowing you to fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up to a day without news. The quality of the radio is excellent, but the size is a bit big. The clock has a self-power back-up and a wide snooze bar. Unfortunately, the controls are a bit fiddly and the tuning is crude. However, the buzzer is effective and the radio quality is fine.

'A hedgehog is a small mammal that has sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many different places around the world. They can roll into a ball when they are attacked. The number of spines a hedgehog has affects its ability to defend itself. Some hedgehogs have evolved to carry out weight, and they have fewer spines. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep for much of the day. Not all hedgehogs hibernate, some will stay awake all year round. '

To excel in any sport is difficult, even for men. But women have to be even tougher. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, so sacrifices must be made. Despite the challenges, women are breaking records and achieving their goals.
Here, we talk to just a few brilliant British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.
A. Jill is a skier. She says, "It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land cleanly, but it can be scary. You just get on with it. It's not easy to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months of the year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice."
B. Caroline is a cyclist. She says, "I'm well paid as a pro, and cycling has lots of potential in terms of endorsements. However, I know I'm not ugly and it worries me that people may think I've got where I'm because of how I look, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I tend to concentrate on the cycling at the moment, rather than earning money."
C. Annabel is a rower. She says, "Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools do it. So most don't start till they're 19 or 20 which makes it harder to succeed at an international level."
D. Ffyona is a long-distance walker. She says, "I was doing 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours sleep in high temperatures and walking with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record!"
E. Lisa is a saloon car racer. She says, "Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, the men think 'I've got to beat her', so I've had a lot of knocks! You have to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's very difficult to earn any money and what I do make goes back into the sport."

I was travelling around Europe and Morocco when I met Picasso. He was eating lunch at a restaurant in Cannes harbour. I was a student and I was drawing. I had a sketchbook and I asked Picasso if he would sign it. He agreed and he inscribed his name on the paper. He also added a flourish to the drawing. Picasso's art was usually anchored in observed reality. I was delighted to meet Picasso and I thanked him for signing my drawing.

Talking shop is a common experience. Sometimes, you buy more than you intended to buy. Supermarkets use different techniques to make you spend more money.
One technique is to make the store look fresh and inviting. They may have fresh fruit and vegetables at the front of the store, or a display of flowers. They may also have a bakery that smells like fresh bread. The store's fixtures may also be colored to make the store look fresh.
Another technique is to make the products look more desirable. They may display the products in a way that makes them look like they are more expensive than they are. They may also use bright lights to make the products look more appealing.
A third technique is to make the store layout more confusing. They may spread low-priced staples around the store, making it difficult for shoppers to find the items they need. They may also use different carpeting to guide shoppers along a certain path.
Finally, supermarkets often use promotional techniques to attract shoppers. They may have giant photographs of food that are very tempting. They may also have video trolleys that advertise products as you shop.

Sea, Ice & Rock Mountaineer Chris Bonnington and Robin Knox-Johnston are famous climbers and sailors. They have climbed and sailed many mountains and oceans. One day, Chris and Robin were invited to sail and climb in Greenland. They wrote a book about their trip called Sea, Ice and Rock.
Chris and Robin were working on a book called Quest for Adventure. They asked each other to join them on a trip to Greenland. They sailed and climbed for a while and then anchored. They spent time exercising Robin's skills at climbing. Chris showed Robin how to climb and Robin showed Chris how to sail.
The trip to Greenland was difficult. There were many challenges, but Chris and Robin worked together to overcome them. They built a strong friendship during the trip. They were able to trust each other and work together to achieve their goals.

Apples have been with humans since the beginning of time. They are grown all over the world. There are many different kinds of apples. Some apples are red, some are green, and some are yellow. Apples are often eaten with meals. They can also be used to make juice, cider, and other drinks.
In the past, people used apples to make medicine. They also used apples to trade. Apples are a very important part of history. They have been used in many different ways throughout time.

The runner Richard Nerurkar is one of the top 10,000-meter runners in Britain. He visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. The camp is located ten miles south of the equator. It is a beautiful, but lonely and isolated, place.
The training camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mt Kenya. The athletes live in cinder-block dormitories and train three times a day. The daily regime begins at six in the morning and includes a leisurely run, interval training, and a steady run in the late afternoon.
The athletes eat a simple diet of tea, bread, eggs, ugali, stew, and cabbage. When the day's running is over, the athletes relax and bathe in the streams that run off from Mt Kenya's shrinking glaciers.
By the time Nerurkar left the camp, he was even more appreciative of Kenyan success. He couldn't stop himself pondering upon a rather different explanation: that the purity and simplicity of the mountainside lifestyle, these gruelling work-outs and this passion for success, perhaps these are the secrets, perhaps these are the real reasons behind Kenya's rise to the top of world distance running.

Advertising is not doing well. It started to decline early in 1989, well before the recession really began to bite. The main problem with advertising is that it has not been able to keep up with the pace of economic change. As a result, most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised.
When you're watching TV, you probably see a lot of commercials for brands you don't buy. Most people only register a tiny number of advertisements they see and ignore the rest. This is called waste.
However, advertising can still be cost-effective. Millions of advertisements have proved that it is. Advertising has to communicate with large numbers of people to reach the relevant minority. If the advertiser knew exactly which people were going to respond, there would be no point in using media at all.
So, if you are an advertiser, you need to make sure your advertising campaign is tightly targeted. If you can net one million new customers (2 per cent of the adult population), you will be doing well.

Solar Survivor Charles Clover visited a very environmentally-friendly home in Britain. The house is called Southwell Minster and it is located in Nottinghamshire. It has a lot of interesting features, such as rainwater harvesting, sewage recycling, and solar power. The house is also very well-insulated, with triple-glazed windows and airtight doors.
The Vales, who designed and built the house, are serious about the environment. They wrote a book on green architecture back in the 1970s. They designed composting earth closets, lowered rainwater tanks into the cellar, and specified copper gutters to protect the drinking water.
The house is very comfortable to live in. It is warm in the summer and cool in the winter. There is no need to use heating or air conditioning. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove in the hall.
The house is also very economical to run. It costs very little to build and maintain. The Vales pay no water bills. And last winter the house used only nine units of electricity a day costing about 70p.

Arthur Conan Doyle, a writer, believed himself to be a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies that he thought were scientific proof that these tiny creatures really existed. He published the photographs alongside an article he wrote, acknowledging fairies as supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two ladies who took the photos admitted that they were fake. They simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick undermines a basic principle of photography, that the camera cannot lie. But it can, and always could. Today, we use software to edit our digital images. It is a myth that photography ever had a true age of innocence. From the moment cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being altered.

Blacksmiths have been working with iron for many years. They have made weapons, armour, and farming tools. They have also been praised for their artistry. In the past, blacksmiths were very important people. They were like doctors and astrologers. Today, blacksmiths are not as important, but they are still skilled craftsmen.
There has been a recent revival of blacksmithing. People are interested in decorative architecture and less conservative design. There are a lot of events happening to promote blacksmithing. One of the events is an exhibition of forged ironwork. The exhibition has a lot of pieces, ranging from bookends to a spiral staircase.
Many blacksmiths are fascinated by iron. It is a tough and demanding metal. But it is also a very rewarding metal. Iron has given man a lot of visual pleasure and a feeling of security.

I stopped smoking a few months ago. It was a difficult decision, but I was determined to do it. I had been smoking for many years, and I had been trying to quit for a long time. Finally, I decided to go to a stop-smoking session. It was a group therapy and hypnotherapy session. It took place exactly two months and three weeks ago. I did not want to stop smoking, but I knew I had to do it for my health. I found that it was easy to quit smoking. The physical cravings and the pangs of desire for nicotine faded after a few days. I was able to work to deadlines without cigarettes. However, I did find it difficult to potter around at home on weekend mornings. I am increasingly coming to the view that smoking had a great deal to do with displacing boredom.

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British scientist who won the Nobel prize in chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. She was also the first woman to win a Nobel prize.
Hodgkin was devoted to her scientific work. Her most important successes were solving the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel prize for chemistry in 1964, and of insulin, which her group solved in 1969.
There is much to learn from Hodgkin's life. She was a successful scientist and a loving mother. She was also a woman of great determination and perseverance.

Margaret Wilkins has a special ability to find water. She can hold a forked hazel stick above the ground and detect water. She is very busy these days because there has been a lot of drought. Most of her customers are farmers with wells that have dried up. To find water, Margaret needs nothing more than a forked hazel stick. She starts by looking at a map of the area and then walks over the fields with her stick. If she finds water, she will reel slightly and use the stick to locate the exact spot where they should drill. If she and her husband disagree on the location of the water, they will keep looking until they agree.

We changed lives for a day! Have you ever dreamed of swapping lives with someone else for a day? It would be more fun to do something quite different for a change. We fixed it for four people - read how it went.
Amanda, a young mother, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who works as a waitress at a restaurant. Amanda had a busy day taking care of her two daughters. Cindy had a busy day working as a waitress. She spent most of the day standing up and speaking to customers.
Rosemary, a farmer, swapped lives with her friend Hilary, a teacher. Rosemary had a busy day milking cows and making ice-cream. Hilary had a busy day teaching children and inspecting sheep.
D. Hilary's story I arrived at White House Farm at 8.30 am, bright and early, only to discover that Rosemary had been up for three hours. The process of milking cows and making ice-cream is very tiring. I found it quite a lonely day.

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is strange that many musicians, even leading ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a musician who has established himself as unique among the world's trumpet-players today. He was born in Sweden and has a successful career.
Hardenberger started playing the trumpet when he was young. He was given a trumpet as a Christmas present and he started practicing every day. He was taught by a teacher named Bo Nilsson. Bo was a very good teacher and he helped Hardenberger to develop his skills.
Hardenberger has won many competitions. He has also played in many concerts. He is a very popular musician. People enjoy listening to him play the trumpet.

New book A is a story about a fictional republic called Efica. The author has created a world with its own history, traditions and customs. The book is also notable for its humour and the author's unique vision.
The book follows the lives of several characters, including Harriet, a middle-class architect, and Sheila, a traditional working-class woman. Their lives are shattered when their teenage son, Joe, is viciously attacked in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened.
The book also includes a story about a young protagonist named Throfinn Ragnarson, who disappears abruptly at one point in the book, only to return after the Second World War. And there is a story about Aurora Greenway, a spirited woman who approaches her seventies with her companion, Rosie Sunlap.
The author is skilled at exposing the haunting sadness that hovers beneath the seeming ordinariness of life. He is attuned more to the shadows than the bright lights of human activity and identifies the randomness of events.

Linda is a chauffeur. She has to be careful not to get too tired and has to be able to concentrate fully on the road.
D. The Landscape Gardener
Tracy is a landscape gardener. She spends a lot of time outdoors and has to be physically fit.
E. The Civil Engineer
Zena is a civil engineer. She has to be able to work well under pressure and be able to find solutions to problems.

Six people talk about their typical working day.
A. Credit Card Executive
I get up early and go to work. I manage all the customer development programmes for our regular credit card users. I have to keep in touch with existing card users and acquire new ones. I also manage all the advertising for the membership programme across Europe. I have meetings scheduled for most of the day, but I always keep my door open for anyone to come and ask me questions.
B. Record Company Executive
I get to work and go through the post. I listen to demo tapes and sign bands. I start on the first album and oversee budgets and spending. I also go to gigs and socialise with other musicians.
C. Sales Director
I get up and drive to work. I open the post and check if we're going to see any clients that day. I love taking people round the showrooms and selling furniture. I also do the accounts and tax returns.

Tim Pozzi is a 34-year-old who decided to go backpacking this summer. He was inspired by others who had taken the plunge and felt that it was time for him to do the same. He was nervous about leaving his job and his routine, but he knew that he had to do it.

The home office of Georgina McGuiness was transformed into an efficient workplace thanks to the use of computers. The Tartan Museum is a modern museum in Scotland. It has a lot of interesting objects. The museum is located in Edinburgh, a historic city. The museum building is very impressive. It has a huge, yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings.

The end of print may take some time. It's a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change can be frightening and challenging, but it also means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future. Newspapers are facing a decline in sales, but their websites are growing. The decline in print sales is happening in many countries, but the growth of online reading is also happening. Books are also facing a decline in sales, but e-readers are booming. There are a lot of factors that are affecting the decline of print and the growth of online reading. People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A photograph with someone in it is usually more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. To photograph people well, you have to be conscious of actions, gestures and expressions. You also need to be aware of the camera's effect on these.
To photograph people effectively, you should follow these steps:
1. Group people in a way that is visually appealing.
2. Help your subject relax and find a comfortable position.
3. Avoid making it seem like you are taking a picture when you are not.
4. Make eye contact with your subject or have them concentrate on something within the picture area.
5. Use expressions and gestures to convey the subject's mood.
6. Consider the background of your subject and make sure it is relevant to the picture.
7. Include interaction between people in your shot.
8. Take pictures of people in their environment to show where they were.
By following these steps, you can take better pictures of people.

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates illusions of reality through her paintings. She is not interested in being known as the artist who created the work, but rather the artist who made it possible. Janson has been painting trompe-l'oeil for sixteen years and has a string of major corporate and private commissions behind her. Much of her work is inspired by architecture or made for architectural settings.
When Janson finishes a painting, she often feels that she has not done it justice. She is also brutally honest about her 'failings' and is frank about her mathematical abilities. Despite her inclination to play down her talent, Janson is constantly busy. She is generous in praise of her clients and is always willing to listen to their ideas.

In today's workplace, emotional intelligence (EQ) is becoming increasingly important. It is the ability to understand and manage your own emotions and the emotions of others. EQ includes basic elements such as self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social adeptness.
If you have high EQ, you are more likely to be successful in your job. You are also more likely to be able to work well with others. In fact, studies have shown that people who have high EQ are more likely to be promoted and earn higher salaries.
There are many ways to improve your EQ. You can learn about the different elements of EQ and practice them in your daily life. You can also seek professional help if you need it.
In conclusion, emotional intelligence is a valuable asset in the workplace. It can help you to be more successful, happier, and more productive.

The media can earn money from content they don't own. Social media has made it easier to capture newsworthy events. Sometimes, journalists use images from social media to report on news stories. Unfortunately, some reporters have published user-generated content (UGC) without permission. There is a debate about whether it is ethical to use UGC without permission. Research shows that a lot of people film or photograph news events. This means that UGC has a big part to play in the future of the media. To keep the public's trust, the media needs to take steps to ensure that people are properly rewarded for their work and that permission is always sought.

Ancient Chinese medicine, also known as acupuncture, is a traditional Chinese system of medicine that has been used for centuries. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture's role in treating pain has been the most popular.
Acupuncture points are located along meridians, which are lines of energy that flow through the body. When the flow of energy is disrupted, the body becomes unbalanced and can become weak or sick.
To treat pain, acupuncturists use fine needles that are inserted into the skin at specific points on the meridians. They may also use warmth from smouldering herbs or pressure at points on the meridians.
Acupuncture can be effective for treating a variety of pain conditions, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. It is also sometimes used to treat other conditions, such as menstrual pain and facial nerve pain.
If you are considering acupuncture for pain relief, it is important to find a qualified acupuncturist. You should also discuss your condition with your doctor to see if acupuncture is right for you.

P. D. James, a best-selling crime writer, is known for her complex and brilliant imagination. She is a quiet and modest person, but she is also very creative. She has written 12 major detective novels that are read by millions of people all over the world.
P.D. James was born in Oxford and grew up mainly in Cambridge. She met her husband there and had two daughters. Her life has been hard, even tragic at times. But she has persevered and has achieved great success.
P.D. James is a great fan of the works of other women writers, such as Iris Murdoch and Penelope Lively. She also enjoys reading detective stories. She says that writing detective stories is a way of bringing order out of disorder.

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is accepted as a genuine science in many countries. It can be used to indicate certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances.
Handwriting can also be used for vocational guidance and as an adjunct to interviews. Many big companies now employ graphologists to analyse the handwriting of potential candidates for key jobs. But most doctors and psychiatrists remain dubious about the value of graphology.
A professional graphologist, Patricia Marne, argues that they should take it more seriously. She believes that handwriting can indicate psychological characteristics as well as certain medical conditions. She says: 'Handwriting is a powerful indicator of social class and intelligence. But more than that, it can be used to assess mental ability and potential, whether a person should concentrate on arts or sciences, and whether they have a devious or open character.'

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. She picks the plants and takes them up to her studio. She takes one flower out and paints it, which might take a few days. Then, she brings in another flower and builds up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.
Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out. The poppies also come out at the same time. She finds it fascinating to see how the flowers change and grow. She has always been interested in plants. She used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside. Nowadays, the garden owes much to plants that originated in far-off lands.

Film critic Mark Adams has been writing articles about films for a newspaper called The Front Page for the last ten years. It was his first proper job. Before that, he had done some reviewing for other newspapers and magazines. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who had also written for radio and television. Tom hired Mark, but he was not primarily a journalist. He had a lot of other ideas. One of his ideas was that a team of critics should take care of the art forms that didn't require specialised knowledge. There would be a weekly lunch at which the team would make their choices from the artistic material that Tom had decided they should cover. It all felt like a dream at that time. It seemed so unlikely that a paper could be introduced into a crowded market. It seemed just as likely that a millionaire wanted to help Mark personally, and was pretending to employ him. Mark felt self-confident. The first time he saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground, then turning to a page on which one of his reviews appeared, he knew where to look. Tom's original scheme for a team of critics for the arts never took off. It was a good idea, but it didn't work out as planned. Mark chose film as his area of focus. Without Tom's initial push, they would hardly have come up with the present arrangement.

I love collecting things. It is a world of passion, envy and enthusiasm. If you enter this world, remember one thing: if you do not fall in love with an object, do not collect it. People have been collecting things since the beginning of time. Some people collect stones and seashells just for the beauty of their forms and colours. I have been collecting all my life. Everything from flowers to pottery and paintings. My first collection was of stones picked up in my parents' garden. I was fascinated by these objects. I am not alone in being interested in collecting objects. One in three adults indulges the same passion.
I have collected items as different as tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember the day that I persuaded a fellow collector of tulips to part with one which I wanted to add to my collection. I planted it and watered it until one year it vanished - stolen by another collector. One collection that I made was of American rag dolls - 350 of them. I looked all over the USA for these dolls, searching out each variation in design with delight. This collection was destroyed when my house caught fire. Next morning, I stood inside the front hall and saw the remains of furniture and my collection. I am not certain which saddened me more! It is, I suppose, the way that collections change hands that has always interested me.

My job is to put together temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. I have to plan and design the exhibition, and promote it. I also have to make sure the public can understand the thinking behind the exhibition.
My other job is to teach London taxi drivers. I see what new maps and documents need to be produced and I help students learn the 'runs' or routes necessary to pass the test.
My third job is to work as a marine conservationist. I live by the coast and work from home. I help people understand the life underneath the sea.
My final job is to publish maps and atlases. I have to make sure that the publishing programme matches market requirements and ensure that we keep stocks of the books that we publish.

A chalet girl's work is never done. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. She works for a company that provides chalets for skiers. In the yard, there was an old brick building and a lot of sawdust. There was a lot of sawdust covering that part of the yard. One afternoon, Michael was bored and he climbed up the old building. He sat on the roof and looked out at the lake. Suddenly, he said, "I dare you to jump down." He jumped off the roof and fell on the sawdust. He lay rolling around and laughing. The other fellows followed him up the roof and jumped down. They were all laughing and having fun. Michael was still on the roof, watching them. He was sad and lonely. He stayed on the roof for a long time. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped off the roof. He lay there for a long time. There were no sounds in the yard. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump. He got up slowly and walked home feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everybody.

If you are unhappy with your job, you can talk to a careers adviser. They will ask you to write a brief history of yourself and then give you a summary of the findings from a number of tests known as 'psychometrics'. Based on this, they will suggest various careers and the retraining needed.

If you walk into W. Lloyd Jerome's dental surgery in the centre of Glasgow, you'll see bright paintings on the wall and a comfortable blue couch. Jerome says that many people are afraid to go to the dentist. To make people feel more relaxed, he has tried to create an environment where people are not afraid. He also uses a special instrument that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, rather than scraping them.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to do research into dental techniques. He found out that when you make it easier for the patient, you make it easier for yourself. He sees his patient-centred attitude as the start of a gradual movement towards less formality in the conservative British dentistry profession.

Chocolate, which is made in South America, is popular in many countries. People in Britain spend a lot of money on chocolate at Easter and Christmas. Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies the chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to gather samples, and then three hours to get back up to the surface. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released.
Last year, Rachel dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site which was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands. Here, on the ocean floor, is a huge area of underwater volcanoes.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two thirds of her salary comes from teaching.

**
I was dirty, smelly, hungry and tanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body and mind couldn't handle any more. I said, "Never again," as I stepped onto home ground. The train ticket allowed me to travel all over Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've slept in the corridor of a train. Carrying all your possessions on your back in a rucksack makes you have a very basic approach to travel. It encourages incredible wastefulness that can lead to burning socks and getting rid of books when finished. But this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. You can travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. Only by actually seeing Europe, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind.

**
There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport overseas and finding that your baggage has been left behind. If your luggage is not there, you will have to wear the clothes you stand up in for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. Sometimes, airlines lose luggage, even the best ones. It is impossible to guarantee that your luggage will go on the same flight, particularly when there is a change of aircraft. To make sure your luggage arrives safely, you should choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If you have to change planes, try to fly the same airline throughout and allow more connecting time. If your luggage is still missing after all this, you must contact the appropriate airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report (PIR).

The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers. It feeds on fish. The bird cuts like a laser through the scene, straight and fast. It has gone in a split second, but a trace of the image lingers. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers at an early age. He spent a lot of time watching them. He also took pictures of them.
The kingfisher is a popular bird to photograph. It is easy to watch from a hideout. You can see the kingfisher's colours and movement. Charlie James' first hideout was an old blanket which he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favourite spot. The bird came back within minutes and sat only a metre away.

Becoming a conductor is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. Anne Manson was asked to help on an opera the next season. She was nervous at first, but she was able to take the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. She has also assisted Abbado on several more projects.
B. Andrew Constantine won a major competition in 1991. He is finding it difficult to lose the 'competition' label. But orchestras are now inviting him back.
C. Wasfi Kani loves the long practice period which is part of any opera production. She started conducting seriously in her late twenties.
D. Roger Vignoles started out as a resident musician with an opera house. He was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival.
E. Wayne Marshall was noticed by a conductor in 1986. He has conducted a musical in London at short notice.

If you're thinking of taking children to a theme park in Britain, there are many to choose from. We asked five families to test the best. Fun Island is a big theme park with lots of rides for younger children. The kids all loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's also a special ride for very young children. For older children, there are scarier rides, such as Splash Out. After five hours, Steve and I were ready to call it a day, but the children objected because they were having such fun.
Wonderland is another popular theme park. It has a lot of rides for all ages. The older children enjoyed the ferris wheel and the toy cars. We spent six hours there and were glad that there were places where you could put your feet up.
Adventure World is a well-designed theme park. It has a lot of rides for younger children, such as Toy Land and Running River. The park is so well designed that even queuing for rides isn't too boring.
The Great Park is a small theme park that is perfect for younger children. It has a lot of rides that are not too terrifying. We all adored Exotic Travels, a boat ride which starts off quite tamely and then becomes terrific fun.

Five women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside. They all have different businesses and different challenges.
A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She has a lot of customers and she can work from home.
B. Maggy Sasanow works from home as a designer of greetings cards. She enjoys being independent and she has a big room upstairs.
C. Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business. She has seen good times and bad times, but she is still working.
D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business. She enjoys being able to work when she wants to and she publishes books from all over the world.
E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business. She started small and has grown her business to be very successful.

Meet the Watkins family. They are musicians. The sons are composers and prize-winning musicians, while Dad makes the instruments.
John and Hetty Watkins needed to get their son, Paul, a cello. They couldn't afford to buy one, so John decided to make one himself. He took evening classes and learned to make instruments. He made a cello for Paul and another one later.
Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from an early age. Paul learned to play the cello and Huw learned to play the piano. Paul won a competition and was appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra.
The Watkins family is proud of their musical achievements. They are excited to see what their sons will accomplish in the future.

**
The National Trust is an organisation that protects the British countryside. There is a warden named Gareth Roberts who works for the Trust. He says that a National Trust Warden needs to have common sense and be good at handling people. Gareth was born and bred on the Lleyn Peninsula and he has a lot of experience farming. He won the job because of his local knowledge and farming experience.
Gareth's job is to make sure that things get finished, with as little fuss and as economically as possible. He also enjoys talking to the public. But he doesn't like it when people are rude or demanding.
If you have plenty of common sense and you like the idea of an outdoor job, you might think of applying to become a warden like Gareth.

Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is captain of the England team. She has a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She teaches at a local school and has a training session in the local supermarket car park.
The World Championships are big and there will be a lot of pressure on the team. The first game is against Barbados. The team is ranked fourth in the world, but the Championships will be tough.
Kendra is proud of her team and she is excited about the Championships. She has a strong mental attitude and she leads by example. She also thinks it is important to have a good training program and to be able to concentrate on your movements and your feet.

If a child has a natural talent for music, it can be difficult to know how to develop and encourage their gift. Many parents may not recognize or respond to their child's need until frustration explodes into difficult or uncooperative behaviour. Most schools are not able to deal with children who are especially able in music. If a child has a lot of musical ability, they may benefit from the education offered by a specialist music school.
There are five music schools in Britain that offer a sympathetic environment for gifted children aged between seven and eighteen. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on musical activities, such as individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting and theory. They also spend several hours a day practising in properly equipped private rooms.
The main disadvantages of attending a specialist music school are the cost and the fact that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school. If you are considering sending your child to a specialist music school, it is important to weigh the pros and cons carefully.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. They left plants that appealed to Susan. She also inherited the gardener, Danny.
Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. She picks the plants and takes them up to her studio. She takes one flower out and paints it, which might take a few days. Then, she brings in another flower and builds up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.
Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out. The poppies also come out at the same time. She finds it fascinating to see how the flowers change and grow. She has always been interested in plants. She used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside. Nowadays, the garden owes much to plants that originated in far-off lands.

A chalet girl's work is never done. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is a chalet girl in Val d'lsere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in the chalets.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet. She has breakfast and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she clears up and makes the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible.
In the evening, Sarah prepares dinner and takes a shower. She doesn't sleep. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. After dinner, she clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares tea for the new guests. Sometimes she takes guests down to the ski shop and gets a lift back to the chalet. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends.

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the office of the magazine Marie Claire. She had to wear a different outfit than her usual uniform. She went to a photo studio, press previews, and a fashion shoot. She also visited the zoo and gave animals a cuddle.
Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant, spent the day at London Zoo. She wore a polo shirt that the zoo gave her. She stroked an elephant and thought about Mandie packing up clothes.
Karen Hodson, a nurse, went on location with the television gardening programme Ground Force. She was excited to meet the team and felt weak compared to the rest of the team.
Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and handed out tablets. He felt his job was a waste of time compared with nursing.
Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. She felt different when she put on the uniform and felt self-conscious.
Sonia McDermott, an air hostess, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was surprised to see that some of the trainers didn't eat ultra-healthily. She wouldn't swap her job for this, but it has inspired her to join a gym and try to be a bit healthier.

Five celebrities tell Andrew Morgan their favourite memories of railway journeys. They all have different stories to tell. Andrea Thompson loves the south of France. Raj Patel enjoyed a train journey across the desert in Sudan. Betty Cooper remembers her honeymoon journey to Egypt. Martin Brown had to take a train across a desert in Africa. Arisu Mezuki made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire.
They all agree that train journeys can be very enchanting. They feel like they are travelling through time and space. The trains are often filled with interesting people. There are tourists and locals, all with different itineraries but all admirers of the breathtaking journey.

If you want to get your story published, there are a few things you need to do. First, you need to research your markets and find out about publishers. You also need to practice your writing skills. To become a successful writer, you need to develop a knowledge of the markets you are aiming at. You can do this by reading everything relevant you can lay your hands on. You should also get familiar with the kind of stories publishers are actually accepting at any given time. Once you have done all of that, you can start writing your story. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not likely to be published. But don't be discouraged. Just keep writing and eventually you will get your work published.

On the last day of a bad year, I was waiting at the Baltimore railway station for the 10.10 to Philadelphia. There were a lot of people waiting. The station was not clean and polished like it usually is. There were elderly couples and college kids with their bags. A man was walking around talking to different strangers. He looked well-off. He went up to a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. He also came over to me and asked me if I was travelling to Philadelphia. I said yes, but he didn't ask me to go with him. He was probably worried about his wife. He was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have been the logical choice. I let my eyes wander toward the two of them. It looked like he was trying to hide something.

John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, a famous TV chef. Everyone has a chance in life. Gary was given his chance with cooking. John ran a restaurant and he was able to provide for his family. He lived over the restaurant and put a lot of emphasis on having meals together. His children, Gary and Joe, are both very confident. Gary was a lively child and he loved to cook. He started cooking at a young age and he was very successful. He went to catering college and he started his own business. John is proud of Gary and he thinks that he has achieved a lot.

Finding a good flat in Dublin was like finding gold in the gold rush. If you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a place, that often worked. But if you had just arrived in Dublin, there was no chance of any personal contact. You had to stay in a hostel and search.
Jo felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to go and work there. She didn't ask herself why she was going there in the first place. She was heading off on her own.
There was an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend that said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was very near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true.
The flat was upstairs and there was a cheerful-looking girl coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.'
Jo went on climbing and met a punk named Pauline. She had seen some of them on O'Connell Street, but hadn't met one close up to talk to.
They were just about to have a mug of tea and Jo introduced herself. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I rang.'

**
Dolphins are popular animals that people love to see. They are intelligent and sensitive to human emotions. They also allow us to dream of freedom. However, dolphins are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and human disturbance.
There are many different kinds of dolphins. Some dolphins live far out in the open sea, while others live near to coasts. The bottlenose dolphin is one of the most common kinds of dolphin. Bottlenoses are particularly social and live in groups. They are often seen flashing quickly past ships.
One of the biggest threats to dolphins is pollution. Pollutants can build up in the bodies of dolphins and can cause a number of health problems. Another threat to dolphins is overfishing. If fish are removed from an area, dolphins may not be able to find enough food to survive. Human disturbance is also a major threat to dolphins. Noise pollution from ships and other sources can disturb dolphins and make it difficult for them to communicate.
Dolphins are an important part of the ocean ecosystem. They help to regulate the food chain and they are a source of joy for people all over the world. It is important to protect dolphins so that they can continue to live and thrive.

Getting fit is important for your mind, body and spirit. It's a great way to stay healthy and happy. There are many reasons why you should exercise. It can help you to improve your muscle tone, strength, posture and flexibility. It can also help you to prevent injuries, relieve stress and improve your mood. If you're not sure how to start, you should talk to your doctor. You can do many different types of exercise, such as aerobics, jogging, working out with weights or stretching. To get the most out of your exercise, you should warm up before you start, stretch after you finish and do a cool down period.

In their natural habitat, film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman are often away from their home comforts for months on end. They are searching for the perfect shot. Two of the hardest creatures to track down in East Africa are Amanda and Owen. Their present habitat, the Ngorongoro Crater, has been affected by a lot of rain. They had to invest in an expensive piece of equipment to help them when their vehicles get stuck in the mud. Their partnership has created some of TV's finest wildlife films. They are often travelling to remote areas to film animals. They have to put up their tents each night and make their tea the night before. Their diet consists of pre-packed meals that are heated and dished out by whoever is at hand. It can be a rough existence, but the appeal of being alone in such remote areas is that they can get close enough to the animals to become part of their lives.

Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is very busy with her training and the upcoming World Championships. She has a typical day which includes teaching and training. She said that she is too focused on her movements and feet to see anything else while she is playing. The World Championships are very important to Kendra. They are her fourth championships and they are guaranteed to be the biggest ever. The team is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra says that the championships will be tough. She also says that the sport has become harder and faster since she started playing. As captain, Kendra has a strong mental attitude and leads by example. She is excited to lead her team out in the opening candlelight ceremony.

The dive can last for 16 hours. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released.
Rachel has made six dives. Last year she dived with a Russian crew. Here, on the ocean floor, is a huge area of underwater volcanoes.

First impressions are often lasting ones. People form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement and how fast or slowly we talk, our volume and tone of voice as well as our actual words.
Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and was confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. However, she didn't get the job. The Head Teacher said that if someone doesn't take the time to present their best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?
It is important to have a professional image and to communicate clearly. If you want to do well in an interview, you should dress professionally, make good eye contact, and speak clearly and concisely. You should also be prepared to answer questions and show that you are interested in the company.

Matt Froggatt used to be an insurance agent in London but now he runs a sheep farm. He was made redundant and decided to set up the farm. He is glad he is no longer stuck in the office but he still has a lot of work.
Ron Able was a manager in advertising but now he makes a living as an artist. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. He is happy that he is able to express himself creatively.
Katherine Goodison set up her own business making hats for private clients. She was tired of working long hours and decided to leave her job as a lawyer. She is happier now and feels less stressed.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur. He was unhappy with his job and decided to change careers. He is now happy and feels in control of his destiny.

Four young sports stars talk about their lives. They are all dedicated to their sports.
Darius is a runner. He has always been sporty and played a lot of different sports. He was best at football and athletics. He competed for his country and won a medal. But he didn't get much media attention. He has to train hard and eat healthy.
Gabriel is a surfer. He loves surfing and is very serious about it. He has to cut out late-night parties to be successful. He won the National Championships last year and got picked to present a surfing series on TV.
Dieter is a yacht racer. He loves sailing and is very traditional. He celebrates a win in great style. But he doesn't like being recognized.
Tomas is a tennis player. He loves playing tennis and is very serious about it. He has to travel a lot and make sacrifices. But he is content to concentrate on his game now and catch up on other things later.

Young shoppers often go to the supermarket with their parents. Sometimes, they want everything they see. If it's not the latest cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, all three. Sometimes, parents have a lot of trouble deciding what to buy. They feel guilty if they say no to their children's demands. And they feel bad if they give in to their children's demands. Sometimes, parents are inconsistent and hypocritical. They refuse to buy their children sweets but they buy double cream and chocolate for themselves. Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict. They could remove sweets from checkout areas or provide supervised play areas.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been built using the latest technology. The hotel has a lot of technology that makes it very comfortable for guests.
The hotel has a computer system that can deal with return clients and store their preferences. It also has a system that controls room temperature. Guests can change the temperature themselves or have it adjusted by the staff. The hotel also has a lot of other amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is a luxurious and comfortable place to stay. It is likely to be a popular hotel for business and leisure travelers alike.

**
I get my energy from doing things I enjoy. I like to dance, write, and spend time in nature. If I'm feeling bored or sad, I know that doing something creative or physical will give me energy.
I also get energy from being around people. When I'm with friends or family, I feel happy and energized. If I'm feeling tired, I need to get some sleep or do something relaxing.
There are a few things that I don't do that give me energy. If I eat unhealthy foods or drink alcohol, I feel tired. If I don't get enough sleep, I also feel tired.

Ice skating has a long history. People have been skating for thousands of years. In the past, people used skates made from animal bones. Now, people use skates made from metal. Skating is a popular sport that can be enjoyed by people of all ages. To skate, you need to be relaxed and have good balance. You also need to know how to fall safely. If you are new to skating, you should start by learning the basic figures. Once you have mastered the basic figures, you can move on to more advanced moves. Skating is a great way to improve your balance, coordination, and strength. It also improves your heart and lung health.

If there's one thing that can make you cry, it's seeing a child win a medal. Julia Gregson asked three young stars, and their mothers, to talk about their lives.
A. Annika Reeder won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete at the next Olympics. It's hard to be a gym star, but you have to be very dedicated and work hard.
B. Annika's mother said, "From an early age, Annika showed tremendous potential. To perform at the level she does is very demanding. But it's also very rewarding."
C. Sarah Stokes made her first show-jumping appearance at ten. She has won the British National Championship. Show-jumping is a fun and exciting sport. You have to be very talented and well-trained to be successful.
D. Sarah's mother said, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse, she knew she loved it. To qualify for major shows, you have to jump all over England. It's expensive to travel, so we sleep in the living quarters of our horse box."
E. Jane McShane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. Chess is a friendly and fun game. You have to be very smart and focused to be successful.
F. Jane's mother said, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. If she has this gift, let her fulfil her potential."

Chris Greener was tall when he was fourteen. He is the tallest man in Britain today. Every year, more and more people are born who are tall. This does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors used to eat a wide variety of foods, but today we mostly eat three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice and maize. This poor diet has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. The problem is that we cannot grow for ever. We must have some programmed upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, of University, it could be as much as 193 cm - and we are likely to reach it some time this century.

Studio audiences are a common feature of television life. They are made up of people from all classes, professions and income groups. People go to studio audiences for different reasons. Some people hope to appear on television, others are curious to take a look behind the scenes, and still others just want to have fun.
When you sit in a studio audience, you are squashed among strangers and someone flashes cards with AUD or LAUGH on them. You clap or laugh accordingly. It may reflect the reality of some television, but not all by any means.
Going to a studio may be a terrible way to watch television, but that's not what's important. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**
Bruce likes landscapes that have a human element. He finds it important to have people in the landscape. When he travels abroad, he likes to visit lovely villages with old temples. He also likes to explore the countryside. He finds the landscape familiar yet different from his home in Scotland. He used to describe his adventures in his private diary. That was his first attempt at travel writing.
Sophia likes a miniature railway that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. She always travels first class. The scenery is not spectacular. But there is one point on the journey that she always looks forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. She sees herself in the eyes of the people who live in the houses.
Matthew likes the Hartland Peninsula. The beaches are hard to reach and scattered with rocks. There are coast walks which you can combine with trips inland up beautiful damp valleys.
Annette likes the Trough of Bowland. It's a landscape of wide-open moorland which is perfect for hiking. There are not many residents and not many visitors either. It's an unknown corner, empty and remote, and she likes the feeling of space.
James purchased Glenthorne, his favourite house in Britain. It's a magic, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except sea, wind and birds.

We love animals. One day, my daughter found a pine snake. We decided to keep it overnight. We set up a special tank for the snake. It was a long day. There was a lot of confusion. The snake escaped. I was scared. I tried to catch the snake, but I failed. Finally, I managed to catch the snake. I was happy. I looked the snake over for weak points. It didn't have any. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer. The snake relaxed. I slowly moved the snake away from my property. The snake went away. We were all happy.

In our busy world, people use phones, fax machines and computers to communicate. But there is something special about receiving a letter that cannot be matched by any other form of communication. It's the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it is from and the enjoyment of the contents.
I have been writing letters for as long as I can remember. I started writing to my mom when I was young. My mom also taught me to write thank-you letters for Christmas and my birthday. I would write to my mom and dad once a week when I went to London to train as a doctor. Sometimes my dad would write and it was always a joy to receive his letters.
I also have penfriends from all over the world. I have one penfriend in Sri Lanka, one in Australia, one in Vancouver and one in France. I love receiving letters from my penfriends. They make me feel happy and connected to the world.
I am pleased that my children are carrying on the tradition of letter writing. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mom. My son has penfriends of his own in Texas, organised by my penfriend. I strongly urge readers not to allow letter writing to become another 'lost art'.

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into the rocks at Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged. The drawings include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields and various gods and goddesses. But as the popularity of the site increases, the pictures are being ruined by thoughtless graffiti.
The drawings are being damaged rapidly and will not survive for future generations. People are stamping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and definition of the artwork as they do so. Some visitors even chop off parts to take home as souvenirs.
Experts are divided over the best way to preserve the drawings. Some believe that the only way to save the site is to turn the whole mountain into a 'no-go' area. Others believe that the best solution is to let people look at the site but charge a fee.
The site was classified as a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do as much as possible to save what is there. If we do not take steps, the drawings will be lost for future generations.

Once upon a time, climbers went to the mountains. Now, you can climb anywhere, indoors or out. The crowd holds its breath. High above them on the climbing wall, there is a climber named Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. The National Indoor Arena is famous for staging the TV show Gladiators. But the TV show and the World Cup Climbing Championships share one thing - The Wall. And the fact that either event is possible is the result of a new and rapidly developing technology. Before, climbers practised their skills on cliffs. But now, there are many sports centres that have climbing walls. These walls are made of bricks with special edges that climbers can hold on to. You can climb on these walls all year round. But there are some problems with climbing walls. They can only be built in a vertical plane. And they can get tiring to climb. But there is a new type of climbing wall that solves these problems. It is made of steel and has interchangeable fixtures. This type of climbing wall is perfect for climbers of all levels.

**
If you want to be an actor, it's a risky career. There are a lot of actors, but not enough jobs. If you choose to become an actor, people may tell you you're crazy. But it's a personal choice and only you can take responsibility for yourself. There are no easy ways to become an actor. You need luck and talent. There is a demand for new faces and new talent. Acting is all about making contact with the audience. If you ask actors how they have done well, they will not know. They will know certain things about themselves and aspects of their own technique and the techniques of others. But they will take nothing for granted. Disappointment is the greatest enemy of the actor. You need to be prepared for rejection. If you don't care enough, no-one will care for you.

We have a special selection of cookbooks that are perfect for beginner cooks. There are two main types of cookbooks: those that teach you the basics of cooking and those that provide recipes.
The first type of cookbook is Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course. It has everything you need to know to cook basic and advanced dishes. It also has hundreds of delicious recipes.
The second type of cookbook is Raymond Blanc's book, Blanc Mange. It has over 80 amazing recipes that are perfect for beginners. It also includes tips on how to cook certain ingredients and how to troubleshoot common problems.
If you are looking for a cookbook that will teach you the basics of cooking or provide you with delicious recipes, then one of these two cookbooks is perfect for you.

Chris Greener was tall when he was fourteen. He is the tallest man in Britain today. Every year, more and more people are born who are tall. This does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors used to eat a wide variety of foods, but today we mostly eat three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice and maize. This poor diet has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. The problem is that we cannot grow for ever. We must have some programmed upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, of University, it could be as much as 193 cm - and we are likely to reach it some time this century.

Matt Froggatt used to be an insurance agent in London but now he runs a sheep farm. He was made redundant and decided to set up the farm. He is glad he is no longer stuck in the office but he still has a lot of work.
Ron Able was a manager in advertising but now he makes a living as an artist. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. He is happy that he is able to express himself creatively.
Katherine Goodison set up her own business making hats for private clients. She was tired of working long hours and decided to leave her job as a lawyer. She is happier now and feels less stressed.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur. He was unhappy with his job and decided to change careers. He is now happy and feels in control of his destiny.

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are playing a game called pichenotte. It's a game that their grandfather brought to the USA from Canada. The game is popular in their town of Santa Fe in New Mexico. It's a game of skill and it's fun to play.
The game is played on a wooden board with 12 pieces called pucks. You flick the puck with your hand and try to get it into a hole. If you get the puck into the hole, you get 20 points. If you get the puck into one of the rings around the hole, you get points too. The game usually lasts just two minutes.
The Lagasses have made a lot of pichenotte boards and they sell them to people all over the world. They're made of birchwood and mahogany and they weigh 12kg. You can buy one of their boards for $595.
The Lagasses are happy to spend their off-duty hours playing pichenotte. They hope that their game will make their fortune.

Welcome to the Model Village. When you first enter the village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago, this was just wasteland. The village was built by one man, Colin Sims, and his wife. They worked hard to change the wasteland into the beautiful village you see today. Many tons of soil and clay were moved to create the village. The land was shaped and top soil was brought in to create the lawns, flower-beds and rockeries. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted in the village. The models in the village are made from a variety of materials. They are very detailed and well-made. You can press buttons to make the models operate. We hope you enjoy your visit to the Model Village.

**
Every week, British newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often include celebrities and other people who are in the public eye. Sometimes, these pictures can be very damaging to the people who are pictured. However, very few people call on the services of the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which is an organization that was set up to deal with issues of this kind. The PCC has not launched an investigation into any of the recent stories about celebrities' privacy. This is a scandal. The PCC should also be looking into the outrageous story published recently about a pop star's love life. If the PCC decided to take on the role of 'police officer', which it technically could, there would be several problems. However, there is no easy solution to this serious problem.

A lot of advice is available for college leavers heading for their first job. If you are taking a real step on the career ladder and choosing a job to fit in with your ambitions, you should choose your second job very carefully. You should be aiming to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be studied very carefully when you send your letter of application for your next job. It should show evidence of serious career planning. Most important, it should extend you, develop you and give you increasing responsibility.
If you are thinking of travelling, now is the time to pack up and go. You can do temporary work for a while when you return, pick up where you left off and get the second job then. Future potential employers will be relieved to see that you have got it out of your system, and are not likely to go off again.

Confident people have learned that confidence is a skill that can be learned. There are many things that you can do to become more confident.
Some people become confident by working hard and being popular in their work. Others become confident by taking on new challenges and completing them. Still others become confident by learning new skills and being able to use them in their daily lives.
If you want to become more confident, there are a few things you can do. First, you need to believe in yourself and your ability to do things. Second, you need to set realistic goals and work towards them. Third, you need to be patient and persistent. Finally, you need to surround yourself with positive people.

Paul Forster went to a kite-flying festival in Malaysia. He spent a nervous night in the forest. He was given a kite that was traditional and had a lot of decorations. The festival was big and there were many people competing. The kites flew high into the air like rockets. There was also a lot of music and dancing. Paul stayed in a hut in the forest and enjoyed the peace and quiet. He also went hiking and saw a lot of beautiful scenery.

What kind of shopper are you? Everyone goes shopping, but there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which kind you are? Abby Edwards asked around and found out that there are different types of shoppers. Some people are addicted to shopping, like Melanie and her boyfriend. They love spending money and they often drag each other around the shops. Other people are reluctant shoppers, like Brenda. They don't like spending money and they usually get their husbands to do the shopping. Still other people only shop for essentials, like Juliet. They only buy what they need and they find shopping tiring. And there are people who like a good look round, like Anita. They know what they want and they get it quickly. Finally, there are people who dislike shopping, like Lizzie. They find it noisy and overwhelming.

'If you want to get a degree, the Open University can help you. You can study at home and continue to work. It also offers a lot of new opportunities. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning new things. You will make friends with people from all over the world. You may also find that your qualification provides new career opportunities. To find out more, you can complete the form below. It could be the start of a wonderful new period in your life.'

During the Easter holidays, young visitors can take part in a quiz on Surprises. The quiz sheets are free and can be picked up from the desk at the Orange Street entrance. Children will be asked questions about 14 surprising paintings. The quiz sheets will be available from 25 March until 9 April.
The Gallery has a new picture by the Dutch painter Jan van Os. It is a large picture of flowers and fruit painted in light, bright colours. It is one of the first pictures of this type in the Gallery.
The Gallery also has a special exhibition called 'Painting in Spain during the late 18th century'. The exhibition features works by three Spanish painters of this period. The exhibition runs until 31 May.
Free guided tours of the Gallery take place every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays).
